description.text:
Recently i had to repair an aging Dallas 1 Wire Weather station, the cups on the anemometer were all but completely gone and the wind vane was a stick with no tail!
I mixed these together and they work great!
I printed them both as 100% solid objects at .2 layer height, the anemometer needs to be printed with support for best results. Both of them have a hexagonal indent on them to capture the inward nut that sits on the shaft to space them from the body of the device.
The holes for the shaft is slightly undersized, i prefer to make things this way so that i can precisely enlarge them to the correct size for a snug or loose fit depending on what i need so you will have to drill them out to the final size. To set the nut in place in the indent, its a very tight fit and is meant to be pressed in, i take a machine screw of the same thread and spin the nut on to it then put it through the anemometer or wind vane and then put a large thick flat washer on the other side and another nut and tighten until the captured nut is pressed into the part to keep it captured. Then a small flat washer and a nylock lock nut to hold them onto the shaft to prevent future problems.
Works great, the accuracy seems to be about what it was. One last note, its ABS and not entirely UV resistant, so to make them last i lightly painted them with two coats of Krylon Fusion white spray paint to help them stand up to UV, this has worked great for me on other outdoor projects and its been a proven method for me.
The other problem these stations suffer from is the bearings inside will seize up and wear into the plastic. I am working on designing some replacement parts to modify the inside to better capture the bearings as well as purchasing better quality bearings. They are 10mm outer diameter, 5mm inner diameter and 4mm thickness roller bearings. Will update when i can!
Edit.. Forgot to add the source of the Anemometer that i re-mixed and added to, thats now included below! Wanted to make sure i credited that fine design!
I played around with his scad file for a while until i got the sizing right then i added the hexagonal support for the nut inside. I also added the files for the bearing support replacements. Typically the bearings freeze up then they spin and eat away at the plastic inside the housing. So i designed some new pieces to repair it. Lower is the wind vane, upper is the anemometer. So the files are labeled if held in that orientation. They are slightly different and you might want to measure the bearing to bearing distances to make sure yours is the same, some slight production changes seemed to have happened over this stations lifetime. To fit the lower-upper and the upper-lower bearing cups you need to cut a circle out of the center of the housing. Included is the Bearing Cut Guide, which is a disk that you can lay over the inner bearing opening and trace to mark the half circle of material you have to remove from both halves of the housing. All of the bearing pieces are sized to allow a 1.5mm washer to be stacked with the 4mm thick bearing to provide a better wear surface for the bearings to sit against, you place the washer between the bearing and the replacement bearing cup to prevent wear on the plastic. If you want to omit the washers you can order a 5.5mm thick bearing instead. The Shell Bottom, Shell Top, and Mounting Adapter is for replacing the entire housing if you just need a whole new one from scratch! If you can't repair your housing just print a new one! The Mounting Adapter allows it to be attaching to a piece of pipe easier and just slip fits onto the shell, to use it you have to leave out the screws in the shell that interfere with it and then i just glue on the adapter instead. So far its been holding up great!
100% Infill with support.

title: Printrbot Simple 1405 Y & X tensioner replacement

description.text:
My Y tensioner snapped on my Simple 1405, so a Printrbottalk.com member inspired me to design one. I have not had a chance to print this as my printer is out of order currently, but there should be no reason why it doesn't work.
Print at 70% or more infill.
The F and Y represent the front portion, this should be facing the motor/outward. The OrF is just a signature.
The belt holes are angles for strain relief and to make the angle of the belt on the back to be less-sharp.
There are nut holes for nuts, they will still protrude slightly, but should stay in!
If there are any size issues, please let me know. This will remain a WIP until someone can confirm that it fits properly.
Update 16 June 2014: X tensioner added, it is a bit longer than the original but should be ok. A WIP until confirmation.

Print at high resolution (.1mm layer height is what I would use), 70% or more infill. Do a slow print as the part is small.
Use M3 bolt and nut!

comments.text: Hi, I just wanted to say I ended up using your X tensioner when I installed an XL size bed. I didn't realize it, but the original wood tensioner was broken, which I only discovered when I was installing the new longer belt. It has worked really well, I used some nylon locking nuts to avoid loosening by vibration. They had a snug fit, but to be safe, I put a dab of super glue to help hold them in place. Inserting the belt was quite tight, it took a lot of worked with a razor blade and forcing the belt through the holes to make it work, but I didn't calibrate the printer before printing the tensioner, so that was most likely the source of the problem. I can't remember how the old wood one fit, but your longer tensioner touches the edge of the metal bed, but so far it doesn't seem to skew it enough to cause an issue. Thanks for posting this!
comments.author: kahrendt

comments.text: Thank you for letting me know it worked. I had to make it a few mm longer to have the nuts be in the tensioner itself, I'm glad it worked for you.

description.text: I now consider this to be obsolete. I get great results with a recent version of Slic3r, in combination with sailfish on my thing-o-matic, without any additional hacks. Try it out!

This is my Slic3r settings for Thing-O-Matic, including a postprocessing script to create the correct extrusion commands. These settings works great for me, although I haven't really measured and calibrated the result yet. Feel free to share your experience and improvements! Files are also available in this gist:
https://gist.github.com/4250182

• Load the ini-file
  • Place tomfix.py in the same directory as Slic3r.exe (on Linux you might have to add the entire absolute path to the script in slic3r's config)
  • tweak your speeds and anything else you might want to.
  • Generate g-code and check that the post-process script ran correctly (the first line should contain the following: "Processed with tomfix.py", otherwise you will have to check your console output for errors.
  • Load g-code into ReplicatorG and press Build
    • Please note that the speeds are adapted for accelerated build with the jetty firmware. If you use the vanilla firmware, you will probably have to decrease the speeds a bit.

title: Baby Gift: Cuddling Owls on Name Plate

description.text:
I wanted to give a 3D-printed gift to friends with a newborn. They created an owl-themed baby room so I wanted to give the well-known these cuddling owls, but with the name of the baby girl on it. So I made this simple remix.  
There's also space on the back of the plate to add an extra text like the (birth)date or your own name.  
I created it in Cinema 4D, so the C4D R15 file is included to change the text. Choose any font you want. The STL has no text, so you can add extruded text with your 3D program of choice.

author: EagleMachine2662

description.text:
Kuro's Compact Bowden Geared Extruder UPDATE: gears should fit each other with less slop now. Designed to fit a Rostock Mini, this design can be used in other printer adjusting the support, that is fixed on two of the extruder motor bolt holes. It uses a MK7 drive gear and 625zz bearings.
The only thing I didn't really like on this extruder is the use of a 3/16" nut to fix the PTFE. It's troublesome to assemble and I really prefer using the press fits. It's recommended to fit the 3/16" nut and then fixing the PTFE in the extruder the first thing, or you will have some bad time fixing it after assembly of the extruder.

Printed Parts (minimum)
  • Extruder body
  • Idler
  • Gears
    • Hardware (minimum)
  • 2 springs for idler tension
  • 3 625zz bearings
  • 1 MK7 drive gear
  • 1 M5x40mm hex headed bolt
  • 1 M5x30mm bolt
  • 2 M3x35mm bolts
  • 1 M3x20mm bolt
  • 2 M3x10mm bolt
  • 1 3/16" nut
  • Assorted nuts and washers

comments.text:
I like your fan, but may I offer a design change to make this thing highly efficient?
The venturi is also a nice design!
comments.author: aquaculture01

comments.text: Nevermind, I just saw that hoverhead addressed the issue as far as efficiency goes. I just din't want to give my input without asking as I am sure you put quite a bit of time and effort into this thing. I don't like knocking people down, but would rather help them out.

Also Stuey, just to shed some light on why the design should be changed F.Y.I. , the tallest part of the fan blade is pitched in such a way it is meant to push air outward, more so than passing it through. This sharp pitch near the hub that pushes the air out-word allows it to collide/combine with the air that is being pushed through the fan at the ends of the blade (nearest the housing) where you have more velocity of the blade itself, in turn giving the prop more efficiency with compression which is what you want, especially with a venturi. Efficiency is key when incorporating a venturi since it forms a pressure chamber. If this fan blade is not designed correctly you may even get better results as far as thrust goes without the venturi or narrowed exhaust porting. It greatly depends on rpm's as well as number of blades and their pitch, also the blade to housing clearances. Once you reverse the curve of the blades as well as operating rotation, try it out without the narrowed exhaust porting. If you get better results, you can incorporate a solid ring around the entire prop and do away with all of the housing, with exception of the motor mounting section of course. One more thing.....make the cutting edge of the blades as narrow as possible to minimize as much resistance and or turbulence as possible. Hope this help you out bud, you got the C.A.D. part down to a tee!

Hi thanks for the pleasant comments and I'll take it all on board. I would be interested to see the changes you'll make. I spent about 1 hour on this after learning CAD for about a month so I kinda just wanted to publish something and see if I could draw it.
Still learning today as I don't get a massive amount of time to spend on it.
Thank you, Nice pusher fan.

description.text: spacecraft deck and tube

Piece that attaches wheelchair legs to a shopping cart, so that wheelchair users are able to use the shopping carts in grocery stores while also pushing their own wheelchairs as they cannot do both at the same time normally.  
Need for these is great because usually the only other option is the electric shopping cart and there are normally only one of these in a whole grocery store so it is not enough.

Design is a short 6 inch cylindrical piece with hooks attached on both ends. You would need to print one out for each leg. The hooks are so you can change the orientation depending on how the shopping cart is designed. One end of the piece would hook or ‘clip’ onto the leg and the other end would do the same on the shopping cart.

title: Tree Topper - illuminated Star of David

description.text: Another in the multi-cultural holiday ornament series. This to top your tree or bush with a glowing flourish

There are two parts, the lighting element is optional. The star features a hollow core which will directly slip over the top branch. If you do not ad lighting thats it.
If you choose to illuminate, use standard 9V LED strip lighting (available on Amazon). Cut to size and fold in half.  Print the 9V battery holder assembly (which will clip to the base of star). Prepare the snap-on 9v batterv connector (available at Radio Shack) by adding longer leads and either soldering to LED strip or use a snap connector. (a switch could be added if desired) Insert the battery into the holder assembly then slip the strip into the Star core sideways so the lighting illuminates both sides. Slide the star into the Battery holder (the shorter clip) then slide the entire assembly over tree top the longer clip.
Print at .25 layer height (or better) with translucent PLA or I expect white ABS would work. fill should not be greater than 10% for best illumination. 
Turn on Vince Guaraldi's "Christmas Time is here" and enjoy a Potato Latke. 
Files are on TinkerCad.

title: RM Mobile One v3 center hinge cover

description.text:
The Mobile One is a (sadly discontinued) series of laptop from RM, designed for use in schools. Children are a destructive bunch of disgusting creatures, and so this laptop is made to endure them. Hard screen cover, shock absorber corners, and a case seemingly constructed from the same adamantium alloy that coats Wolverine's skeleton. The weakest point is the center cover for the hinge, which protects the delicate display and wireless cables. Though secured by several screws and additional plastic latches, some of the more determined larvae can still snap it off and lose it.  
This model is designed for strength, minimizing the snappable parts. It fits snugly (I know, I've used one) and keeps the wires covered, and if you print it in black it looks almost like the original.  
There's a catch, though. The only way to attach this back in place is via glue. Specifically, solvent cement - nothing less will hold. That cement doesn't work on PLA, only on ABS. So if you want to get this attached properly it must be an ABS print.  
Note that this is for the widescreen model only - it won't fit the older 4:3! I've fitted one to a v3, but I don't have access to the v1/v2 so I don't know if they use the same hinge cover.
Use ABS! PLA won't take the adhesive, and it's too weak to withstand the destructive impulses of youth.

Okay, this really isn't a thing but I think it's worth uploading. SuperSkein is a first-order model slicer that runs in Processing. It's pretty basic still, but since it's object oriented and in Processing (which could be quickly ported to C) it should be easy for the community to hack and improve. Right now it slices models in /seconds/ that'd totally bog down Skeinforge and can slice models with non-manifold errors without a problem. It's missing nearly all of Skeinforge's features, but I've got a MakerBot to print a more-or-less-viable object from it already. Happy hacking! EDIT: Added 1.1 with some niceties added and one of the big basic bugs fixed.
Also also edit: Now on github!
http://github.com/MaskedRetriever/SuperSkein
If you want collaborator access just message me or comment!

Step 1: Unzip the folder and put it into a directory named SuperSkein, then run SuperSkein.pde with Processing!
Step 2: Hack until satisfied :3

While exploring The Public Domain Review, I stumbled upon a collection of the more inventive submissions to a London Tower Design Competition held in 1890. This is the first in a series of my own interpretations of those ideas that I'm calling the "London Tower Project". London Tower Design Competition: This competition, which yielded some irresistibly imaginative ideas, was the British response to the overwhelming ovation recieved by the unveiling of Eifel Tower in Paris in 1889. At the end of the competition DESIGN No. 37 by Stewart, McLaren and Dunn was chosen to be built in Wembley Park, but unfortunately after a series of issues with the foundation and funding the project was abandoned in 1892 and the remaining structure removed a few years later in 1905. With the exception of DESIGN No. 37, these wonderful concepts never saw the light of day, until now! My London Tower Project strives to explore the imagination of a past generation through the actualization of these design submissions. Check out the other designs in the collection: http://bit.ly/DesignALondonTower

This is a simple design for a swing-away clamp for holding 6mm toothed belts in place.  It's not designed to handle very high loads, but should be sufficient for most simple uses.
Put an M3 screw and nut through one of the mounting holes and insert the belt into the slot.  Swing the arm down and use another screw to pin the arm in place.

comments.text: Nice and simple. I almost get a bigger kick from shared little solutions to very common design problems, than from full-up death star plans. :-)
comments.author: syvwlch

description.text: This is the power resistor heater block described by nophead on http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2009/01/yet-another-quick-heater-hack.html (nophead, if you want to make a thing for this, I'll take this one down and post my pics as a copy, or I can just change the license to one of your choosing) made from the kit available from http://www.makergear.com/products/ceramic-heater-core (choose "Power resistor heater kit"). The power resistor acts as a heating element to heat an aluminum block around the heater barrel, replacing the nichrome in other hot end designs. It's installed in my oversized Mini Mendel Huxley (which has BARELY enough space in the bottom of the X carriage. Hopefully the radiating heat won't screw up the carriage, but I plan to make a new one when I get it printing anyway. Thingiverse is flipping some of my pictures upside-down for some reason, I'll try uploading them again later.

You need a block of aluminum at least 19x19x8mm (mine is about 20x20x13mm). Using a drill press if you have one (I don't), drill a 5mm hole on one side for the heater barrel through any dimension (I would have tried making it through the longer dimension, but my barrel was too short) and tap it with a 6mm, 1mm pitch tap. Drill another hole through the long dimension the size of your power resistor (6.5mm was too small for mine, and 7mm needed some aluminum foil padding). Drill a third hole just large enough and deep enough to embed your thermistor. Being sure not to short your leads (the makergear kit comes with some thin PTFE tubing for insulation, and I also used polyimide tape to seal it up), wire the resistor and thermistor to your extruder controller.

comments.text: How is this heating? Is it reaching the appropriate temperatures for extrusion? Power issues when hooked up directly to the extruder board?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I rebuilt it in a vertical orientation for better thermal conduction and wrapped a couple of layers of ceramic insulation tape around it. It now heats fairly quickly ( considering the mass) and I got it up to about 350 C once when the controller failed to turn off power to the heater.

This is a tool for turning the hubs on a 2000 Ford F350 4X4 truck.  The hubs get difficult to turn as they get old, so this saves having to replace the hubs just because they are difficult to turn.

I made this on my R2 using supports and 100% infill.  100% infill is required because there is a lot of force going through this tool if the hubs are stiff (and if they aren't stiff, why would you make this?).
I designed this in SolidWorks in about 15 minutes, starting with dimensions from the truck hub.
Works great on my truck!  If your hubs have an ID of 2.5" and a flange thickness of 7/16", this should work for you too.

description.text: No sharp corners to hurt yourself.

Print two times.
Open-side-down down worked best for me. Instert a BB (4.5mm steel ball). Use instant-glue to CAREFULLY join halves.
Trust me, having both index fingers glued to it sounds more fun then it really is. Paint it, write on it, or modify the file and include numbers in the print. Note: thinnest part is 0,6mm, it might not print well on some settings. Perhaps if you scale it up 10% you will get better results. But it's basically just 6 spheres combined with a larger sphere, then enclosed by a big sphere, and finaly cut in half. A free cookie to the person who will create a parametric version! ;-)

description.text:
Stick it to the man (figuratively only please!) with this open source, fun and completely functional butterfly-comb!
All the flash and guile of a butterfly knife, but your fingers get to stay attached to your hands!
Based off of Techno264's excellent design, this blade has wider, curved teeth which print easily and won't break off.  Also, the comb now has a blood groove, and an angled tanto point for an aggressive look :)
The butterfly-comb is completely harmless, fun to play with, and a you can really comb your hair with it!
It prints in minutes, so you can use it to impress friends when giving a demo of your 3D printer :)
I will be posting a video about the comb on my site shortly: www.fabberforge.com
Update 12/2/2012 1700:  Added experimental untested comb with pointy teeth :) 
Update 12/2/2012 1800:  Added a second experimental pointy tooth comb :)
Update 12/5/2012 1828:  V2 Comb Blade uploaded.  It is 1mm thicker (more sturdy) and has pointed curved teeth.

• Print One Comb-Blade and Two Handles

  • For assembly, I used:
    • 2x 16mm M3 bolts
    2x M3 nuts
    4x m3 washers (nylon, but metal will work :) ) If the parts are not moving freely, just run a drill bit through the holes :) Find this on TinkerCAD and re-create it as you see fit: https://tinkercad.com/things/lT6ZMXamUIT-open-source-butterfly-comb-blade/edit

title: 20mm pole bracket for filament storage box

description.text: This is a bracket I used to make a filament dry box out of a plastic storage container (Sterilite #1925) and a 20mm dia. metal pole (left over from a shelving unit).  Unlike the other rod brackets I've seen here, these are designed to mount with screws going from the outside in, rather than from the inside out (which wouldn't work very well going into plastic this thin).

You will probably want to use a fairly high infill percentage, so that the screws have something to bite into.  
Drill a pair of holes in each end of the container, 30mm apart assuming that you didn't rescale the design.  Attach using small wood screws (I used #2 x 3/8") and washers.

description.text: 3d printed Jigsaw Puzzle Tiles where initially created for a Tile Game I\\'d been working on. However I\'ve been printing them out for http://www.jigsawrenaissance.org Members to show support. If you are a member and don\\'t already have one (or any one thing that prints out in 15min or less) contact the Jigsaw Renaissance Maker Space or me.

Print out in different colors or natural white. Color or draw designs with sharpies or Rit Dye http://blog.makerbot.com/2010/05/31/dyeing-white-abs-parts/ them to whatever color you want. Version 0.2 pieces are currently only 30mm x 30mm x 1.5mm high for quick printing but can be easily scaled up to the thickness you want. Join the together in anyway you like to create shapes, letters, names, etc. This Version 0.2 should interlock without much play in them. But may depend on how well your machine is calibrated and it\\'s skeinforge settings. Once I tightened up my X and Y axis everything started interlocking better. I\\'ll include Rhino3d source and STEP output a bit later. As well as SVG/DXF if you have access to a laser cutter. (if you do I\\'d really like a set). [UPDATE: July 30th 2010 - nope the tolerances are too close for the pieces to interlock without jamming or forcing them when using the default settings with the new RepG v18. I\'ve gone back and pulled another 0.0625mm off the sides and made them thicker (5mm) so they hold together easily but need to re-upload that version after some more testing.]

As an American, wheels are far better than legs.  So here is my attempt to enhance the Cupcake transformer with this set of 6 wheels.  I've borrowed  the stl for the leg to make it all work together.
The other reason for creating this mod is to try out my designs for a printable axle.  After some trial and error, this is first version that works pretty well

IMPORTANT!  I've devised what should be a printable axle.  This will not work if there are too many strings.  Turning on "comb" fixes this.  Also, this model also works best if it is mostly printed at low temps in order to print the modest overhangs.  I print the first layer on the HBP at 220C and all other layers at 185C (my thermistor uses the suggested settings which may be off).
I did see some error in skeinforge, but everything printed correctly so knock on wood.

Updated concept

wibbeley wobbeley timey wimey - well that is the wrong franchise. I saw Serin117's work and suddenly felt the urge to create one myself with the oddly cut peaces, so I started with a sphere in 123D Design, placed a torus 4 times, subtracted 2 from the sphere and then I started cutting... I almost went crazy, but now i got a real time traveller puzzle! No part is the same! I even accidentally put them in the wrong order :D
Now with holes for magnets the size of 3x3mm as wished by graphmastur (although I chose different magnet sizes) and corrected the nobble positioning. There will be no further iterations, every detail I might have missed will be painted on.
Allons-y! Continuum misses some catchfrases, I guess. Naaah.
First VIDEO https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=21FlNVYqdnM
UPDATE 06/25: The "frankensteined" moved to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:373303
UPDATE 06/24: The "frankensteined" part from episode 3x13 (not printed yet)
UPDATE 06/18: Part 6 was missing a tunnel which got lost at the cleaning process
UPDATE 06/17: Magnet holes and nobbles on a more screen accurate position
UPDATE 10/29: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8WWzKwx72Wk

order some magnets, you are probably doing best ordering bigger magnets then me. I used 3mm radius, 3mm height neodyme N45 magnets, but they are a bit too weak for the task, especially on the center cut, where no piece interlocks. Or you may try at least N52 magnets.

it's obvious... but yeah. They should print without any support, not sure about my infill, I used some honeycomb structure and used about 8-12m of 1.75mm PLA per part. You will need at least 200g of the color your printing.

Sand down the insides so the later glued-in magnets will lock best. Use some putty/bondo/Spachtelmasse for the pipe sections to ged rid of the layer artifacts. Get a soldering iron and put it hot on your printed parts to get the holes and bumps on the shell. To color it I used some silver spray paint for the outside of the sphere and copper spray paint for the pipes.

I'm a bit overly attached to this thingi and always check for remixes, comments, mades and likes etc. and am always happy to see that  someone printed it, so please share your print :) We also have to register where one could be found in times of urgent needed time travels.

title: GPS / Smartphone Cup Holder Car Mount System

description.text:
Very simple GPS/Smartphone cup holder car mount system.
You print what you need and assemble it with nuts and bolts from any hardware store.
The ball mount is design to fit the back of a Garmin GPS.
ALL SOURCES AVAILABLE. Sketchup Models and STL.

1) Look at the different parts
2) Print the Base and Base_up models
3) Select the parts you will need and print them up!
4) Assemble with screws (or inserts and M2 screw if you'd to be fancy)
5) Use it!
** I used ABS since my car tends to stay in the sun a lot. If you print this thing for a vehicle that is normally used in a very hot (or very cold) climate, please make sure you use the right material for your region to avoid a complete part meltdown :)

I've printed this many times and thought, "Why dont I rework the spire to make it a bit more realistic?"
Here is what I've done.

At the current size, the spire gets to be a bit thin. At ~.5mm or so, I suggest you make sure the final layers are printed a bit slower than usual make up the difference.
I print things like this at .25mm layer height. Less than 15 infill, 1 shell.

A secure place to clip your iPhone5, in a vehicle or on a desk!
Snap fit case which snap fits into the positionable cradle arm. Grooves along the edge of the case provide a firm grip in your hand, and in the cradle. Perfect for Facetime! Now you can place your phone for handsfree video chat!

I printed all the components at 25% infill, No Support required. I have included three kinds of feet for the arm.
"Bracket Foot" is just a small flat base.
"Bracket Foot Screw Flange" has a wide base with sunken holes for use with screws.
"Bracket Foot Wide Flange" is a large wide foot, designed to stand on a desk or be fixed to a larger surface. Print out: "Slim Case with Grooves"
"Case Mount"
"Upper Bracket"
"Lower Bracket" and choose one of the three feet:
"Bracket Foot"
"Bracket Foot Screw Flange"
"Bracket Foot Wide Flange" Get a couple of machine screws and hardware like washers and nuts.
I just used some I had laying around, I think they are 4mm x 30mm Socket cap screws. But whatever you have laying around will work.
I happen to have some small threaded dowel pins, and they make it easy to tighten down the joints. Drill out the holes to ensure a smooth fit with your screws. Use some acetone or super glue to attach the "Upper Bracket" to the Back of the "Case Mount". If you assemble the rest of the arm before you glue it, it provides a nicer visual reference to ensure you are perfectly aligned. Also to aid in positioning, use a tiny piece of double sided tape to temporarily position it where you like and lightly trace it with pencil. Remove the tape and glue in place. Use an exacto knife to clean around the power button in the case. If you notice the button is hard to press, remove your phone and LIGHTLY wiggle the button to pre-stress it. Possible uses:
Desktop Cradle
Vehicle Mount In my car I have a recessed area ahead of the shifter knob. This has been designed to be mounted to the front surface of that area. And allow the phone to sit in a nice position just above my shifter.
This could be used on a dashboard also. But for that I would be sure to choose an adhesive that can be removed without damaging the dash finish. Possible enhancements would be rotateable joints and more pieces. Suggestions and Comments are always welcome. Happy Printing!

I wanted a way to quickly mix protein powder in a glass. Doing it by hand was too labor intensive and I didn't get everything 100% mixed all the time and would leave blobs of goop on the bottom sides of the glass. More power was required! I made a slotted adapter that is fitted with two forks and then inserted into a drill. Now I can whisk the powder into its proper slurry in just a couple of seconds and not have any left over blobs. Obviously there are a bazillion different fork handle designs in the world so I can't say this is a universal adapter. The forks I have on hand have handles that are slightly concave so they wedge quite nicely into the slots in the adapter. Video in action
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZScbuGgpFN0

Print out adapter
While print is still warm insert two utensils (forks) into slots. The tines can face each other or away, up to you.
Place adapter into drill chuck
Whisk away

description.text: A printed isolator block which holds 2 M4 bus bolts for power distribution.

You will need... 2 Hexagon Head M4 x 20mm bolts.
2 M4 half nuts
2 M4 lock nuts Slot the M4 bolts into the isolator block, then cover the heads with small squares of insulating tape to insulate from the carbon plate. Then attach to the frame with double sided tape. Fasten down from the top with a M4 half nut then connect your crimped connectors before finally locking down tightly with a M4 lock nut. Note I also solder the connectors after crimping.

title: Braille Scanner/Reader
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This object is designed to scan braille text and read it out loud or store it on internal memory to be translated into typed text in a word document or other text programs.This product could be used to assist people who are blind or partially blind to read braille much quicker and easier. It could also be used to help teach braille to people whether blind or not.The scanner end is angled to allow the scanner to be held comfortable. The bottom half would also be made with a comfortable rubber grip while the top half would be a shiny elegant black colored metal. On the one side there are a volume controls. on the front face there is the power button and built-in speakers just bellow. At the top end there is a headphone jack and mini usb port for easy hook up to the computer. Bluetooth would be built-in to allow the user to not worry about cords. The Devise contains no sharp edges and has a smooth finish to it allowing the user to hold it with ease and comfort. it also has a cap to protect the scanner.  
This is just a conceptual design and does not contain any of the actual technology. A working modal would need several chips. This devise could potential work of a modified arduino or raspberry pi chip that would be customized for the size and shape of the scanner. Other required shields that would need to be add would be a Bluetooth, camera sensors, speakers, buttons and ports.   
I am open to any suggestions you might have to add and am will happy accept new modifications to this design. I think this could be a great devise to assist people who are blind or partially blind and hope to see something slimier mass produced to assist people.

This design was made using AutoCAD 2014 and is just the design.
Notes for Printing:
  • When printing the scanner it is best to remove the center part of the mini usb port due to the support that will get added. The .stl file included already has the center of the mini usb port removed and is ready for printing.
  • When printing the cap, it is best to print it with the opening facing up to reduce the amount of support added to the print. It will also give it a better finish and will take less time to print.

comments.text: Amazing concept here, I've heard of a pen that can read text but the remix for braille is great.  Even if it is conceptual, can I see a BOM for the components you would need to get this working?

description.text:
I designed and printed a suppressor (based loosely on k-baffles) for my air rifle.
It consists of 3 sections - a barrel section that just pushes tightly onto the end of the barrel, an end cap (I've provided 2 different end caps designs), and the k-baffle section - which you print multiple copies of, the more you add the quieter the result.
The sections all push together then can be glued in place. Because each section is small you can make quite a long suppressor regardless of the print volume of your printer.

title: Toyota Air Vent Lever - Open / Close - Tested w/ Mk II Prius (2004-2006)

description.text:
Somehow I lost one of the levers that allows my vents to open and close. So if you spun the little "on / off" knob below the air vent, this wouldn't do anything.
Today I decided to take another one out so I could copy the missing piece. Attached is my copy. It took about one hour with millimeter ruler, digital caliper, and paper protractor to get it just right.
This will enable you to open and close your air vents if you have the knobs but not the little levers that grab the vents.
If you plan to 3D print, I urge you to consider between v3 and v4. I made v4 just to ENSURE it would grab the vent door and click on.
Also with my 3D printer I used the stove to soften the clip before pushing it into place (didn't want to take any chances) because it has to flex a lot!

1) removed a working vent from the car
2) removed the lever itself from around the vent door
3) measured it carefully, over and over, while adding primitives to my design
4) checked my design against my own vents to ensure they would
(a) grab the vent doors without falling off and
(b) spin when the knob was turned.
It's important to have the following tools to manually copy such an object:
1) digital caliper
2) millimeter ruler
3) paper protractor
4) fine mechanical pencil or ultra fine tipped marker
And it's important to have the following tools if you wish to completely hand-finish the part to your own satisfaction:
1) micro torch / soldering iron (hot knife tip)
2) rat tail file

author: danfruzzetti

description.text: This advent calendar has (will have) a box for each of the 25 days in December through Christmas, and a small "gift" for each box. The boxes fit together to form the shape of a Christmas tree. I will be posting a box and gift each day until Christmas. I will try to get each day's parts posted the night before, so you will have time to print it on the proper day. This Thing will eventually have all 25 days of parts. I will also post each day's parts as a derivative of this Thing, so there will be a convenient place for any "I Made One" posts of the daily pieces. THANKS TO EVERYONE who contributed ideas for things to make. I got a lot of great suggestions, and I wish I could have used them all. This calendar is my entry into ProtoParadigm's Winter Wonderland Contest. Wish me luck! List of Gifts: Day 1: Wrapped Present Day 2: Wrapped Present (with a bow) Day 3: Toboggan/sled Day 4: X-Wing Day 5: Toy Train Day 6: Snowman Day 7: Candle Day 8: Mug (of hot cocoa, coffee, tea, etc.) Day 9: Church With Steeple Day 10: Igloo Day 11: Gingerbread House Day 12: Makerbot Replicator 2 Day 13: Christmas Tree Day 14: Gingerbread Man Day 15: Bell Day 16: Candycane Day 17: Tardis Day 18: Snowflake Day 19: Santa Hat Day 20: Toy Drum Day 21: Burning Logs Day 22: Plate of Cookies Day 23: Festivus Pole Day 24: Toy Rocket Day 25: Star

1) Print the Gift and Box for each day.  
2) Assemble the Boxes to make a Christmas tree.  
3) Watch for the new parts for each day.  
The All Files archive contains all the STL files, as well as all my CAD files for the parts. The parts were designed in ViaCAD--if you don't have that software these files probably won't be much good to you.
